paper_abstract: Given real numbers ba parts per thousand yena > 0, an (a,b)-Roman dominating function of a graph G=(V,E) is a function f:V ->{0,a,b} such that every vertex v with f(v)=0 has a neighbor u with f(u)=b. An independent/connected/total (a,b)-Roman dominating function is an (a,b)-Roman dominating function f such that {vaV:f(v)not equal 0} induces a subgraph without edges/that is connected/without isolated vertices. For a weight function , the weight of f is w(f)=a (vaV) w(v)f(v). The weighted (a,b)-Roman domination number is the minimum weight of an (a,b)-Roman dominating function of G. Similarly, we can define the weighted independent (a,b)-Roman domination number . In this paper, we first prove that for any fixed (a,b) the (a,b)-Roman domination and the total/connected/independent (a,b)-Roman domination problems are NP-complete for bipartite graphs. We also show that for any fixed (a,b) the (a,b)-Roman domination and the total/connected/weighted independent (a,b)-Roman domination problems are NP-complete for chordal graphs. We then give linear-time algorithms for the weighted (a,b)-Roman domination problem with ba parts per thousand yena > 0, and the weighted independent (a,b)-Roman domination problem with 2aa parts per thousand yenba parts per thousand yena > 0 on strongly chordal graphs with a strong elimination ordering provided.
paper_title: Roman domination on strongly chordal graphs
